nodes.bodyText: [Question] - Should this type of "default" be set on the Server side instead?
This is purely client side option. It is not passed to the service anywhere.
[Nit] dumb question (based on similar change above), when do we use single quote (') vs double quote (") for these types of messages?
There is no guideline here. I would support coming up with one and making sure that all the log messages obey it.
even with the comment, it is still not obvious to me what the difference is between execution latency and execution total latency?
[Nit] also styling question on when to use "//" comment vs "/** */" comment delimiters, as is done below on lines 48, 51

Fixed comments.
To understand this comment you need to know about workflow task heartbeat feature. Basically a workflow task when reporting completion can set ForceCreateNewWorkflowTask property to true on RespondWorkflowTaskCompletedRequest. In this case, the new workflow task is created immediately and returned as a response to the RespondWorkflowTaskCompletedRequest call. Such call acts as a heartbeat that extends the duration of a workflow task. Thus a single total execution latency of a workflow task can be larger than latencies of multiple such synchronously created tasks.
[Nit] no single or double quote delimiters around activityTask here?
Also you can remove the first plus sign and concatenate the first two strings (e.g. "ExecuteLocalActivityParameters{activityTask=" + activityTask + "}"
Curious why some of these methods have full comments (such as startChildWorkflow), but then some like this one (signalExternalWorkflowExecution) don't

nodes.bodyText: hopefully we added a unit test to cover this as this should have been caught when I was syncing to Alex's latest proto changes

Good catch. We had a test that ensured that the worker doesn't spin on the task failure. But after I added an additional check that the task failure is reported exactly once I found that it wasn't doing so. Here is the new unit test and the fix. The unit test fails with attempts condition changed.
[Nit] what does it mean by return "true if new task should be created synchronously"? Does this mean not null?
See my earlier comment about force creating workflow tasks.
we swapped the order to two arguments with the same type...hopefully all the callers have been updated
Agree that it is error-prone. Changed WorkflowTaskResult to use the Builder pattern.
Name of class implies two possible configurations, but it looks like its ActionOrEventTypeOrCommandType (three)

nodes.bodyText: I've added unit tests that demonstrate that these transitions are not possible. The basic idea is that the workflow code always executes in the context of an event loop. It causes activity timeouts to be delivered before the code that causes the timeout which generates the cancel command.

+  private static StateMachine<State, Action, ActivityStateMachine> newStateMachine() {
+    return StateMachine.<State, Action, ActivityStateMachine>newInstance(

+            State.TIMED_OUT,
+            State.CANCELED)
+        .add(

+            Action.SCHEDULE,

+            .build());
+  }
+
+  public void cancel() {
+    if (parameters.getCancellationType() == ActivityCancellationType.ABANDON) {
+      notifyCanceled();
+    } else {
+      action(Action.CANCEL);
+    }
+  }
+
+  private void cancelScheduleCommand() {
+    cancelInitialCommand();
+    if (parameters.getCancellationType() != ActivityCancellationType.ABANDON) {
+      notifyCanceled();

+

+    Failure failure =

nodes.bodyText: (more for my own knowledge than an actual comment), what does "Abandon" mean vs some of the other semantics and why would a developer choose one over the other? Does it mean the server will just perceive an activity timeout vs an explicit cancellation? Or does it mean we will wait for the server to acknowledge the cancel before actually cancelling? Or I guess it means the caller doesn't care to wait for the cancellation to actually be ACK'd, (s)he just wants it scheduled?

+
+  public void cancel() {
+    if (parameters.getCancellationType() == ActivityCancellationType.ABANDON) {

+      explicitEvent(ExplicitEvent.CANCEL);

+  }
+

+    startedCommandEventId = currentEvent.getEventId();

+
+  private void cancelCommandNotifyCancelled() {
+    cancelCommand();
+    if (parameters.getCancellationType() != ActivityCancellationType.ABANDON) {
+      notifyCanceled();
+    }
+  }
+
+  private void notifyCanceledIfTryCancel() {
+    if (parameters.getCancellationType() == ActivityCancellationType.TRY_CANCEL) {
+      notifyCanceled();
+    }

+

+        Failure.newBuilder()

+        .add(
+            State.STARTED_ACTIVITY_CANCEL_COMMAND_CREATED,
+            EventType.EVENT_TYPE_ACTIVITY_TASK_COMPLETED,
+            State.COMPLETED,
+            ActivityStateMachine::cancelCommandNotifyCompleted)
+        .add(
+            State.STARTED_ACTIVITY_CANCEL_COMMAND_CREATED,
+            EventType.EVENT_TYPE_ACTIVITY_TASK_FAILED,

+        .add(

+        .add(

+        .add(

+  private final ExecuteActivityParameters parameters;

Interesting that signalExternalWorkflowExecution is cancelable. What is the scenario for that?

When workflow (or any part of its code) is canceled we automatically cancel all outstanding requests including signalExternalWorkflowExecution. Note that it is cancellable only until the command was sent out to the service.
yeah, that cancellation window seems very, very tiny tbh.
Can we do <= here?
done
[Super-Nit] Canceled vs Cancelled
Canceled vs Cancelled

It looks like we are using Canceled in the API: https://github.com/temporalio/api/search?q=canceled&unscoped_q=canceled
Google says  that Canceled is American and cancelled is British.
I'm going to rename cancelled to canceled everywhere.
[Nit] kinda strange that some of these methods communicate their results via return values while others communicate using instance members of the class.
It would be a pretty large change. So far public methods return values and private ones communicate through fields.

this is a strange name for a variable (timeoutInterval) especially as it just seems to represent the elapsed amount of time / 2? This interval will simply get bigger as the while loop continues to run right?
Refactored this part of the code.
this represents the amount of time the local activity has to execute?
This is the maximum time for local retries. I've made it configurable through LocalActivityOptions
[Nit] double nested while(true) loops with breaks and returns might make this code hard to read
Fixed
typo in comment
so we have NOT_MATCHING_EVENT and NON_MATCHING_EVENT. Can we align these?
Fixed.
any reason this is commented out?
my own learning: i assume that isPresent returns false if the value is identical to the previously stored version, right?
right
does this mean a side effect cannot return a null value?
yes

The above option is used only locally. So validation should be done by the SDK. The maxTaskQueueActivitiesPerSecond is an option sent to the service. We made a design decision to not validate on the client any server-side options.
What are the side effects of not defining the no-op transitions that are command based?
Only defined transitions are allowed. Workflow task fails if command or event is applied to the state that doesn't have a transition defined for it.
Why are events registered/validated, but commands are not?

It is pretty evolved. The short answer is that this validation is required to support mutable side effect and versions which can have events missing for the given state machine. So if event doesn't match then it still can be valid as it just doesn't apply to this specific state machine. The same doesn't apply to commands as they always have to match the state machine that created them.
